Comment: A very interesting NOT BLITZ game, specially the final position and its tactics. It would be interesting, I think, to share thoughts about the game.
The wisest answer, I almost never face. Now, taking the pawn is recommended, but I also tried Bf5, even if it not in the spirit of the opening.

A solw move, many would say. But it is true that Nb4 can be soon a threat. White is not at ease coping with this knight unless with some theory behind.

Uncommitting developement moves. Black is not in a hurry to play e5 and open the column, since it not any ahead in reaching castling.

Finally.
...or Nb6. I can't decide which is better, but I am not too experienced with c5 and this "can't be bad". Even so, the game is pretty "slow" for our standards.
This is a move I consider almost as a defeat, since it doesn't threaten anything. But I have to castle if I want some attacking chances.
This is a move I consider almost as a defeat, since it doesn't threaten anything. But I have to castle if I want some attacking chances.
Testing my cool blood? :-)
Now that I know I can castle whenever I want, I better take care of my complete developement. This knight goes here because I want to keep the c pawn free to defend (c6) or attack (c5) at any moment.
Well, now I feel really safe. White has some more space, but it is not clear how to take advantage of it right now.

A profilactic move... my, this is going to be slow. But I think that white should have taken the chance to occupy the black diagonal with Bf4 at once. So maybe this was not a good move.
Of course, I go into the diag myself!
Not that the dsb is misplaced here.
!? Falling just into the enemy's fire. A mistake, I would say, but black's position seems able to stand it. I've played successfully against such attaks in a number of games.
